comment_text: 2:15 how tf did you take that shot???
Quality content

Curiosity whetter, but not much info.  In the SE USA, we have an epiphytic "resurrection fern" that also survives drought in suspended animation.  Its cells are full of trehalose, a sugar that provides essentially the same hydrogen bonding "structure" as liquid water, so that proteins etc don't denature in its absence.  Of course solutes don't move around  absent a liquid solvent (water), so metabolism has to wait for the return of actual water.  I believe ordinary baker's/brewer's yeast uses the same chemistry to survive in dry state, and would not be surprised if the California stuff in this film were doing the same.
They don't really "live" without water though, do they. They just put their life on pause until the rain comes back.

Hi Deep Lookers! I produced this video about tiny mosses that can survive for decades, even 100 years, without a drop of water. I wrote for KQED about scientists who are hoping to harness the genes in these mosses to make crops that can survive a drought, like the one we're facing in California right now: http://ww2.kqed.org/science/2015/06/25/these-resurrection-plants-spring-back-to-life-in-seconds/
Thank you for watching and reading!
Gabriela
